review_title: For a county hospital? Pretty great
pros:
The people who work here actually want to work here. The nurses could all make more money elsewhere, so there’s a large brand loyalty (and loyalty to the people of Dallas). 
Throughout the pandemic, nurse to patient ratios were never out of control. In the ICU, we were kept 2:1. CRRT remained 1:1 throughout the entire pandemic (and still remains 1:1, which is shocking for most nurses to hear). 
I feel listened to by management, and it does feel as though nursing has a place at the table for some of the bigger decisions.
cons:
Obviously the pay is not as competitive as nearby hospitals. This continues to be an issue, and will always be an issue. Currently, we have a $9 retention incentive, but that’s going away soon and I know it will result in some duress. 

The patients are notorious for being difficult. They are sicker than most, and Parkland is also a chronically-full facility; thus, a patient on a stepdown unit at another hospital would likely only be on a regular med/Surg unit at parkland. They can also just be really mean sometimes (?) despite not paying anything. The only patients I really vibe with are the jail patients, as they’re just super grateful to have a nice bed, a meal, and safety.

review_title: A good place to start a career in the healthcare industry
pros:
Parkland is a good place to start a career in the healthcare industry.  It is also a good organization to have listed on your resume, as Parkland is well respected in the healthcare industry within DFW despite the bad press that's regularly in the media.  

If you are concerned about retirement, Parkland has a "true" pension plan.  That's practically unheard of nowadays.

Many say that Parkland is highly political, but I do not think it's any different than any other organization.  I think it's actually better because although it's highly political, it's scrutinized so much in the media that leaders can't stray too far from doing what's best for the patients and Dallas County taxpayers.

The work is very fast paced, but that's one of the many reasons it's a good place to start a career in healthcare.  The fast paced environment exposes you to areas of the healthcare industry that wouldn't have exposure to in many other entities.
cons:
The PTO structure is a bit awkward.  Holidays are deducted from your PTO bank.  For example, if you have 40 hours of PTO in August, in September, 8 hours of PTO will be taken from your 40 hours for Labor Day.  Their argument is that PTO hours are accumulated at higher rates than other organizations.  That's true, but the overall annual time off each years is still a bit less.

Health insurance is a bit costly and coverage isn't that great, considering Parkland is healthcare facility.

pros: I think working at Parkland is more of a calling than being just an employee. Parkland serves the indigent population in Dallas County - and they need good, smart and dedicated employees and I believe that is what they are. You learn so much working there, not just because of the patient population, but because of the sheer volume of patients seen at Parkland. It's a very special place to grow your career, and you work with a very special bunch of people. Many people spend their entire career working there.
cons: It's a very political place. It's my opinion that the best person for the job is often not the person who gets the job. I sometimes believe that the leadership sells the hospital short by taking shortcuts and hiring who they like and those who are readily available rather than taking the time to do a national search and seeking out the best and most experienced for the job. I've seen so many really good, smart and dedicated people leave or be forced out due to really poor decisions by poor leaders. And I've seen some really unqualified people get really high level positions based on politics - decisions that have left people shaking their heads in disbelief.

cons: One downside of working here was that the hospital was undergoing strenuous periods because it was being reviewed, cited, and threatened by CMS. This made the overall work environment more stressful because management was being watched very closely and managers were ruthless and unforgiving in most every situation. Also, because of the location, Parkland deals with a heavy volume of underprivileged and very low income individuals which can sometimes make for a unsanitary environment. I got both shingles and an unknown rash on my face during the period I worked here. I worked at Parkland while the new hospital was being built and employees were charged weekly for parking and had to take shuttles that had 15 min route times just to get to the building.

review_title: Good for growing within your career, but many internal issues, disorganization and bureaucracy
pros: The pay is decent, depending on how quickly you advance.  You can advance and get leadership positions if you get in with the right people. Tuition reimbursement still available.
cons: Very unorganized and reactive instead of proactive when it comes to handling issues and changing policies and procedures.  Constantly implementing new policies and procedures then change them the next week. Too many "managers" "directors" "vice presidents" who sit on conference calls all day and go to meetings.  You will never see them lay hands on a patient or show their faces to the front line staff.

pros: PHHS is returning to be the gem of Dallas/Fort Worth. After struggling for many years with issues in the C-suite Parkland Hospital is shortly to become the premier Safety Net facility in the nation.PHHS will become a Magnet facility and this will be the result of the hard work and passion of the many rather than the few. PHHS is like a family who welcomes everyone to the table for dinner.
cons: PHHS is a government funded safety net facility and as such struggles to recruit the cream of the crop in nursing staff due to limited funding for staffing. As with most facilities locally we are 25% understaffed. The Office of Talent Management leaves much to be desired as many very qualified candidates never get to the IRONING MANAGER. Change is very SLOW in government agencies.

pros: Great learning opportunities and pay.  The benefits are okay and depending on which department the work-life balance is good.  The employees are good workers!

Super top heaving, hard to move up in the organization due politics, hiring outside and/or hiring friends.  Several leaders are in a position that are not qualified and do not have skills sets to manage situations and department/employees.  The organization is very political and if you are not careful, you can easily find yourself on the list to be thrown to the wolves or out the door.  Wasteful spending and mismanagement of money which leads to laying off employees. Employment practices are unethical which various classes of people are discriminated against and/or jobs eliminated and re-written and less qualified person is hired to replace you at the same or more pay. The organization displays unethical behavior in mistreatment of employees and patients, and does not follow written policy and procedures and always being investigated by the government or sued by employees, patients and vendors. 

Parkland is a jacked organization that ran by a corrupt and racist CEO supported by corrupt and non-efficient Senior Executive Leadership team of legal, compliance, contracts and employment.

Will make us use your own personal time that you have earned to cover holidays and when they are close for holidays such as Christmas, Thanksgiving etc... no sick time earned must straight PTO, no definite policy on bereavement... across the board no structure on when you are given points for taken off, one supervisor can give you a point where as another may not.. I came to work in the sleet and snow in February was late but risk my life to get to work and was still given a point towards firing for showing up late.

job_title: ICU Registered Nurse in Dallas, TX
pros: Direct deposit is always on time.  Black scrub pants are an option.  Hospital t-shirt okay for now (but many threats of ending this).  No real good pros honestly from a nursing standpoint.
cons: Fake shared governance, no respect for clinical nursing staff, no clear promotion or training plans, hard to find policies so most things are based on rumor protocol.   Poor unit managers who are afraid of patient care.   Coffee shop  only open for the administrators (closes around 16:00)  Cafeteria has bank hours.   Don't make this about visitors because we all know better.

pros: Great benefits - medical, dental, vision, 401k, life insurance, disability, etc. for fairly cheap, all paycheck deductible. Ability to move within departments. Discounts for a lot of different things like zoo tickets, sports games, and season passes to theme/water parks. Most employees could make their own schedule, within reason (not on my unit).
cons: Personally, my supervisor was a micro-manager (she was notorious for being a bad manager). The place has a bad reputation (for somewhat good reason) since it is a county hospital, lots of "interesting" people coming in and out daily. Lots of in-services and training because CMS and TJC are on their back all the time. Pay isn't the best, but they don't fire people often so it's a steady job as long as you're a good worker.

pros: New, state of the art building (at taxpayer expense, of course). Parkland is the very definition of "safety-net hospital," for patients who literally have nowhere else to turn. For those who believe that healthcare is a right and not a privilege (and I do,) the new "New Parkland" should be well on its way to meeting the needs of Dallas County residents, and be positioned to implement the necessary policies to meet and enforce all compliance issues with all regulatory agencies far into the future. Pay and benefits were acceptable and competitive. Relationships with coworkers, especially longterm coworkers, is like family. For many, many employees and former employees, Parkland is like a 2nd family. Sitting on the rail line is a huge plus. Some former members of the pharmacy leadership team may have "moved up the chain" but are still sorely missed.
cons: As most people know, the upper management of Parkland totally lost touch with the day to day operations in the prior decade, which led to PHHS nearly being shut down due to the "too big to fail" attitude exhibited by too many managers. Mainly by sheer luck and good fortune did they avoid closure. A LOT of really good people - employees, nurses, allied health professional, and physicians - parted company with Parkland during that painful episode. Currently a "leading" figure of the PHHS pharmacy department, who inherited the job during the aforementioned shake-up, is another perfect example of the PHHS management philosophy, and is evocative of the memories of years of hospital management gone by, when leaders were completely oblivious of what is "really" going on in the trenches. This member of the RX leadership team is out of touch with the RX staff, the patients, the licensed professionals within the pharmacy, and even other managers. Even some more highly-placed members of the hospital's management team are (in my opinion) intimidated by one member of the pharmacy, who makes decisions with an iron fist and manages by fear and intimidation. No one else will make a decision if they even remotely fear that it will displease the one person. Consequently, decisions which need to be made, such as hiring replacements to fill vacancies drag on for months at a time. As a result, this is unfair to the other employees, who have to do their own work PLUS the work of the vacant position, but more to the point, it is unfair to the patients. Ultimately, the patients, and the delivery of quality healthcare to the patients, is the ONLY reason that Parkland exists. This hospital was built and structured (and paid for) by and for the patients, the very residents of Dallas County. When an adequate level of staffing is not provided, be it in Nursing, Pharmacy, or any other department, it is the patients who suffer. And they deserve better. And apparently the JCAHO and CMS agreed, in 2009-2010.

job_title: RN Charge Nurse in Dallas, TX
pros: You cannot beat the experience you get at Parkland, however with more and more level I trauma facilities emerging in the Dallas area Parkland is no longer getting all the cases they once were. Even with this being the case, Parkland is a phenomenal place to begin your career. I had worked at another facility before joining Parkland and you can't beat the work environment and teamwork here at Parkland. Being a teaching facility I have been able to grow from an oncology nurse to an ICU nurse quickly with the support from my coworkers and doctors. There are also plenty of committees to join to get involved, but be careful you don't get over your head and find yourself working 5 day/week due to committee meetings. Compensation is adequate but you would have to leave and come back to really see any significant pay increase.
cons: Just about every ICU management team has some kind of trouble. Almost all managers don't know how to be leaders and they are young. Although they might have the RN experience of 20+ bedsides years that does not equate to being a good manager/leader. My experience has been rough on my unit. Staff turnover rates are high due to lack of support from managers and floating rates are high. It is a one-way street for managers. They ask ask ask but never give. Our unit currently did interviews with the Director expressing out concerns, yet NOTHING was done regarding the manager. If anything was done it was evident that the management team did not like the comments. And when you think about quitting, don't tell a sole. Retaliation is the worst. Managers will threaten saying you will not be re-hirable, I won't give you a reference, or will be shady and condescending your final 2 weeks. I only stay at this hospital because of the patient population and the coworkers. If I could replace the management team with supportive leaders who want to strengthen their staff then I would have a perfect work environment.
